column4: I am trying to mount a ntfs partition but when i try to cd into the mount point i get permission denied
Wrong permissions. How are you mounting it.
i followed the guide form ubuntu
Link me to this guide of yours, please.
Oh, you're trying ntfs-3g? Sorry, can't help you with that; never needed to write to my ntfs partitions.
Then why are you trying to install ntfs-3g?
Don't. Reading is very easy. Do you know the device name (/dev/sda1 or whatever) of your ntfs partition?
Put a line like this in your fstab:      /dev/sda1       /win/C          ntfs    ro,users,umask=000           0       0
adjust to your mountpoint and folder.
ta
the umask=000 basically means "everyone can read this folder". if that's too loose for you, adjust this permission. umask is the opposite of the hexcode you'd use in chmod: chmod 777 = umask 000
when i create the mount point in /media/ do i need to change the permission on that folder?
It won't do any good.
AFAIK.
i did as you said but everytime i try to look at the point i mounted it i get a permission error
That's a configuration file. You'd need to mount the partition.
Keep running "sudo umount <mountpoint>" until it tells you nothing is mounted. Then run "mount <mountpoint>" WITHOUT sudo
Or just reboot. This will sort itself out on restart.
sapage@sap:~$ mount /dev/sdb2 /media/storage/
No.
Keep running "sudo umount /media/storage" until it tells you that nothing is mounted. Then run "mount /dev/sdb2"
cheers feel like a bit of an idiot after that working now :P
Thankfully, you don't have to do this again :) Now that it's in your fstab, it will automount on boot with proper permissions.
Which is what you want, right?
